fields.Title of Contribution: PVAC: Package Version Activity Categorizer, Leveraging Semantic Versioning in a Heterogeneous System
fields.Description/Abstract: <span style="color:#d33682;font-weight:bold;">Context:</span><span style="color:#657b83;"> </span><span style="color:#657b83;">Modern open-source operating systems consist of numerous independent packages</span><span style="color:#657b83;">crafted by countless developers worldwide. To effectively manage this diverse</span><span style="color:#657b83;">array of software originating from various entities, GNU/Linux distributions have</span><span style="color:#657b83;">devised package management tools to streamline the process. </span><span style="color:#657b83;">Despite offering</span><span style="color:#657b83;">convenience in software installation, package managers do not have a</span><span style="color:#657b83;">mechanism to evaluate the version activity of a heterogeneous software</span><span style="color:#657b83;">ecosystem. </span><span style="color:#d33682;font-weight:bold;">Objective:</span><span style="color:#657b83;"> </span><span style="color:#657b83;">The focus of this research is to develop a method to systematically</span><span style="color:#657b83;">determine the version </span><span style="color:#657b83;">activity within package manager systems and score</span><span style="color:#657b83;">each discrete release. Individual packages within a distribution utilize a</span><span style="color:#657b83;">heterogeneous mix of versioning strategies. In their upstream projects, these</span><span style="color:#657b83;">versions are passed through to the package manager, often with distribution</span><span style="color:#657b83;">specific information appended. </span><span style="color:#d33682;font-weight:bold;">Method: </span><span style="color:#657b83;">We developed PVAC a </span><span style="color:#d33682;font-weight:bold;">P</span><span style="color:#657b83;">ackage</span><span style="color:#268bd2;"> </span><span style="color:#d33682;font-weight:bold;">V</span><span style="color:#657b83;">ersion </span><span style="color:#d33682;font-weight:bold;">A</span><span style="color:#657b83;">ctivity </span><span style="color:#d33682;font-weight:bold;">C</span><span style="color:#657b83;">ategorizer to assess the activity of a heterogeneous package</span><span style="color:#657b83;">management system. PVAC uses regular expressions to extract the epoch and</span><span style="color:#657b83;">upstream project major, minor, and patch versions from packages and applies a</span><span style="color:#657b83;">novel method to calculate a score using the Version Number Delta (VND)</span><span style="color:#657b83;">as described by the Community Health Analytics Open Source Software (CHAOSS)</span><span style="color:#657b83;">project. </span><span style="color:#d33682;font-weight:bold;">Results: </span><span style="color:#657b83;">PVAC is able to categorize the semantic version activity of packages in</span><span style="color:#657b83;">heterogeneous package manager systems and employs a novel method to calculate</span><span style="color:#657b83;">the VND. We successfully evaluated PVAC on a dataset of over </span><span style="color:#657b83;">packages from the apt package management system and were able to identify</span><span style="color:#657b83;">packages with high, medium and low activity. </span><span style="color:#d33682;font-weight:bold;">Conclusions:</span><span style="color:#657b83;"> </span><span style="color:#657b83;">We present a novel way to systematically </span><span style="color:#657b83;">evaluate the activity of</span><span style="color:#657b83;">heterogeneous package management systems by examining the semantic versioning</span><span style="color:#657b83;">information of packages. We found that PVAC is a useful tool for assessing the</span><span style="color:#657b83;">activity of packages in a package manager system and can be used to identify</span><span style="color:#657b83;">packages that are actively maintained. We believe that PVAC will be a valuable</span><span style="color:#657b83;">tool for the software engineering research community.</span>
